Mind_Traps.description: Common logical fallacies and cognitive biases, paired with counter-strategies to improve reasoning integrity.

traps.name: Strawman
traps.description: Distorting an opponent's argument to make it easier to attack.
traps.inverse_strategy: Steelman the argumentâ€”represent it in its strongest form before critique.

traps.name: Ad Hominem
traps.description: Attacking the person instead of the argument.
traps.inverse_strategy: Focus on the argument's validity, not the individual's traits.

traps.name: False Dilemma
traps.description: Presenting only two options when more exist.
traps.inverse_strategy: Introduce additional options or question the binary framing.

traps.name: Circular Reasoning
traps.description: The argument's conclusion is assumed in its premise.
traps.inverse_strategy: Identify the lack of independent support for the claim.

traps.name: Slippery Slope
traps.description: Arguing that one event will inevitably lead to another without evidence.
traps.inverse_strategy: Request causal evidence for the claimed chain of events.

traps.name: Appeal to Authority
traps.description: Relying on authority figures instead of evidence.
traps.inverse_strategy: Verify the claim with independent, empirical support.

traps.name: Confirmation Bias
traps.description: Favoring information that confirms existing beliefs.

traps.name: Appeal to Emotion
traps.description: Manipulating emotions instead of presenting rational arguments.
traps.inverse_strategy: Separate emotional appeal from factual support.

traps.name: Post Hoc
traps.description: Assuming that because one event followed another, it was caused by it.

traps.name: Hasty Generalization
traps.description: Drawing a conclusion from insufficient evidence.
traps.inverse_strategy: Check sample size and representativeness before concluding.

traps.name: False Analogy
traps.description: Assuming two things are alike in all respects because they are alike in one.
traps.inverse_strategy: Examine differences that undermine the analogy.

traps.name: Bandwagon Effect
traps.description: Assuming something is true because many believe it.
traps.inverse_strategy: Separate popularity from truth; seek evidence.

Philosophical_Razors.description: Guidelines for reasoning and prioritization, paired with inverse principles and applicable contexts.

razors.name: Occam's Razor
razors.description: Prefer the simplest explanation that accounts for all facts.
razors.inverse_principle: Do not oversimplify when complexity is necessary to capture reality.

razors.name: Hanlon's Razor
razors.description: Never attribute to malice that which can be adequately explained by ignorance or error.
razors.inverse_principle: Consider malice only when negligence or ignorance is implausible.

razors.name: Hitchens's Razor
razors.description: What can be asserted without evidence can be dismissed without evidence.
razors.inverse_principle: Claims with substantial prior plausibility may deserve provisional acceptance.

razors.name: Alder's Razor
razors.description: If something cannot be settled by experiment or observation, it is not worth debating.
razors.inverse_principle: Philosophical or normative issues may warrant discussion despite lack of empirical testability.

razors.name: Newton's Flaming Laser Sword
razors.description: If something cannot be settled by experiment, it is not worth debating.
razors.inverse_principle: Some metaphysical or ethical questions may require non-empirical reasoning.

razors.name: Sagan Standard
razors.inverse_principle: Do not dismiss unconventional ideas if evidence is proportionally strong.

razors.name: Hume's Razor
razors.description: Do not assume causation without empirical evidence.
razors.inverse_principle: Correlation can warrant investigation, but not assumption of causation.

razors.name: Popper's Principle (Falsifiability)
razors.description: Hypotheses must be falsifiable to be scientifically valid.
razors.inverse_principle: Non-falsifiable claims may still hold philosophical value.

razors.name: Grice's Razor
razors.description: Favor conversational implicature and cooperative principle in interpretation.
razors.inverse_principle: Avoid reading implicature when literal meaning suffices.

razors.name: Aquinas's Razor
razors.description: Do not multiply entities beyond necessity.
razors.inverse_principle: Introduce complexity only when needed to avoid explanatory gaps.

additional_razors.name: Hume's Guillotine
additional_razors.description: You cannot derive an 'ought' from an 'is'.
additional_razors.inverse_principle: Values often influence how facts are applied in practical reasoning.

additional_razors.name: Occam's Extended Razor
additional_razors.description: Favor hypotheses that minimize ontological commitment while maintaining explanatory power.
additional_razors.inverse_principle: Reject over-simplification that discards relevant explanatory variables.
